issue.title: winget import not working as expected (does not install all entries)

labels.name: Issue-Bug
labels.description: It either shouldn't be doing this or needs an investigation.

milestone.title: v.Next-Client
milestone.description:
Features and bugfixes to be considered for the next stable release of the Windows Package Manager.

These are considered high-priority or high-valued features for consideration in the next release. Issues may move in and out of this milestone between a scheduled release or the backlog.

issue.body:
### Brief description of your issue

After the reset I expected to be able to run `winget import` to restore all of these apps. However only 4 of the pakages seam to have been attemted to install.

```PS
PS C:\WINDOWS\system32> winget import -i "C:\Users\MartinHinshelwoodnkd\OneDrive - naked Agility with Martin Hinshelwood\Desktop\winget.json" --ignore-versions --accept-package-agreements --disable-interactivity
Found an existing package already installed. Trying to upgrade the installed package...
No applicable upgrade found.
Package is already installed: Microsoft.Edge
The installer cannot be run from an administrator context.
Search failed for: Microsoft.EdgeWebView2Runtime
Found an existing package already installed. Trying to upgrade the installed package...
No applicable upgrade found.
Package is already installed: Microsoft.OneDrive
Found an existing package already installed. Trying to upgrade the installed package...
No applicable upgrade found.
Package is already installed: Microsoft.PowerShell
```

Is there something else I need to do?

### Steps to reproduce

1. winget export "winget.json"
2. Reset Computer but keep files
3. winget import "winget.json"

### Expected behavior

I would expect all of the apps listed in the json to be installed

### Actual behavior

Only 4 of the apps were atempted to install


The log indicates that it is finding the manafest and "running the installer" but that it never actually runs!

issue.title: unpriviledged mode

labels.name: Issue-Feature
labels.description: This is a feature request for the Windows Package Manager client.

issue.body:
### Description of the new feature / enhancement

We (the IT department) want to give our users easy access to common applications and utilities without giving them admin permissions on their workplace-computers. For this use case we would need a mode in which winget only shows packages that can be installed an updated without elevation.

### Proposed technical implementation details

Ideally we would set a system-wide configuration to disable all winget-features that need elevated permissions.

UPDATE:

After reading #388 I assume for this to work consistently, it is necessary to exclude anything that is not an MSI(X) package.

issue.title: unpriviledged mode

labels.name: Issue-Feature
labels.description: This is a feature request for the Windows Package Manager client.

issue.body:
### Description of the new feature / enhancement

We (the IT department) want to give our users easy access to common applications and utilities without giving them admin permissions on their workplace-computers. For this use case we would need a mode in which winget only shows packages that can be installed an updated without elevation.

### Proposed technical implementation details

Ideally we would set a system-wide configuration to disable all winget-features that need elevated permissions.

UPDATE:

After reading #388 I assume for this to work consistently, it is necessary to exclude anything that is not an MSI(X) package.

comment.body:
So this issue depends on [mandatory scope definition](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/issues/2097) in the manifest and something analogous for elevation requirements.

I found that similar topics were discussed in https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/issues/1898, #3240, #2097 and #847. So I close this issue as it doesn't bring new ideas or requirements to the table.

Thank you for the explanations.

issue.title: Better support for Side by Side packages

labels.name: Issue-Feature
labels.description: This is a feature request for the Windows Package Manager client.

issue.body:
### Description of the new feature / enhancement

winget should better support multiple versions of the same package being installed on the same machine.  This happens, and we currently try to pretend it doesn't.

### Proposed technical implementation details

Package detection on the system needs to be improved to correlate package versions together.

Replace `PackageVersion InstalledVersion` with `PackageVersion[] InstalledVersions` internally, then reasoning about how that affects everywhere that breaks.

comment.body:
> Another example of this being an issue would be SSMS. Major versions like 18,19 can be installed side-by-side. Winget would still mark v18 as outdated and show the upgrade to v19.

Well, this happens now and winget installs v19. But it keeps v18 intact, so we run into the issue that winget installs v19 every time `winget upgrade --all` is issued. Like here: #3541

I still have an issue with side-by-side installation of MSSQL Server Management studio.

`Winget upgrade --all` installed the new version 19.1 but left the old version 18.12.1 as-is. When I re-issue `Winget upgrade --all` it installs Version 19.1 again.

`Winget upgrade` comes down to this:

```
Name                                   ID                                  Version          Verfügbar      Quelle
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Microsoft SQL Server Management Studi… Microsoft.SQLServerManagementStudio 18.12.1          19.1           winget
```
I wanted to remove the old version so I searched first usind `winget list --name SQL`.

```
Name                                             ID                                     Version     Verfügbar Quelle
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio - 18.12.1 Microsoft.SQLServerManagementStudio    18.12.1     19.1      winget
Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio - 19.1    Microsoft.SQLServerManagementStudio    19.1                  winget
```
I issued the command `winget uninstall Microsoft.SQLServerManagementStudio -v 18.12.1 --verbose` and now both versions have been uninstalled. This was the output:
```
Gefunden Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio [Microsoft.SQLServerManagementStudio]
Paket-Deinstallation wird gestartet...
Erfolgreich deinstalliert
```
Now `winget list --name SQL` does not list anything any more.

Should I create a separate issue for this? I could not find a matching one.

issue.title: Azure Marketplace images shipping with outdated version of WinGet

labels.name: Issue-Bug
labels.description: It either shouldn't be doing this or needs an investigation.

issue.body:
### Brief description of your issue

The Azure Marketplace image ships with an outdated version of WinGet that no longer works due to the old CDN being retired. As far as I'm aware, there is no way to automate updating WinGet. As a workaround, I am currently having to log in to each image after they are deployed and manually update WinGet via the Microsoft Store.

### Steps to reproduce

Create a new Azure VM using an Azure Marketplace image (I am using Windows 10 (22H2) EVD + Office ProPlus Gen 2), and immediately attempt to use WinGet. It will fail, as the version of WinGet is pointing to the retired CDN.

### Expected behavior

Azure Marketplace images should ship with the latest version of WinGet.

### Actual behavior

Azure Marketplace images ship with an older, non-working version of WinGet.

### Environment

```shell
NA
```

issue.body:
### Brief description of your issue

When an upgrade for an application is available, but with a different installer technology, `winget upgrade --all` lists the app but skips it silently:

![image](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/assets/12860484/57462671-bc00-4ede-8348-b88baf7d7887)

[WinGet-2023-10-27-TrackerSoftware.PDF-XChangeEditor.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/files/13185214/WinGet-2023-10-27-TrackerSoftware.PDF-XChangeEditor.zip)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install TrackerSoftware.PDF-XChangeEditor using the EXE installer from https://www.pdf-xchange.com/product/downloads.
2. run `winget upgrade --all`

### Expected behavior

`winget upgrade --all` should attempt to upgrade the app and complain that it can't with the standard "_A newer version was found, but the install technology is different from the current version installed. Please uninstall the package and install the newer version._" message.

### Actual behavior

`winget upgrade --all` silently skips the app:

![image](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/assets/12860484/25921993-e7e3-478d-b6ed-e3ae6dce19de)

issue.title: unpriviledged mode

labels.name: Issue-Feature
labels.description: This is a feature request for the Windows Package Manager client.

issue.body:
### Description of the new feature / enhancement

We (the IT department) want to give our users easy access to common applications and utilities without giving them admin permissions on their workplace-computers. For this use case we would need a mode in which winget only shows packages that can be installed an updated without elevation.

### Proposed technical implementation details

Ideally we would set a system-wide configuration to disable all winget-features that need elevated permissions.

UPDATE:

After reading #388 I assume for this to work consistently, it is necessary to exclude anything that is not an MSI(X) package.

comment.body:
The installer type is validated.

The part that is unknown (because it is not a requirement in the schema) is whether the scope or elevation requirements are completely accurate.

From an automated validation perspective, we test that the properties in the manifest are correct, but we don't try to validate the cases not declared in the manifest.

For example, a manifest could include scope "user", but may exclude scope for "machine". We wouldn't try to validate that a machine wide installation succeeds in that case because it's support or lack thereof is not explicit.

If a manifest has an elevation requirement, we do not validate that the other elevation requirements would not succeed.

I can point to "Spotify" as an example. It will not run elevated, and the manifest declares this. If this were to change in the future and the manifest was not updated, we wouldn't know to automatically check to see if it could succeed elevated during validation.

milestone.description:

Notable features:
* [Pin a Package](#476) #476

The "Due date" is aspirational and primarily intended to help sort Milestones.

As the date approaches features and bugs may be moved to the next milestone.

issue.body:
### Brief description of your issue

Winget will not update when running as normal user. It will update when run under admin permissions, but then it can not upgrade any app. Updating/upgrading used to work as user.

### Steps to reproduce

```
PS C:\Users\C_B-A> winget upgrade --all --verbose
Failed in attempting to update the source: winget
Name                                       Id                           Version   Available Source
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Microsoft .NET SDK 5.0.214 (x64)           Microsoft.DotNet.SDK.5       5.0.214   5.0.408   winget
Microsoft Visual C++ 2005 Redistributable  Microsoft.VCRedist.2005.x86  8.0.56336 8.0.61001 winget
Microsoft .NET SDK 6.0.203 (x64)           Microsoft.DotNet.SDK.6       6.0.203   6.0.405   winget
4 upgrades available.

(1/4) Found Microsoft .NET SDK 5.0 [Microsoft.DotNet.SDK.5] Version 5.0.408
This application is licensed to you by its owner.
An unexpected error occurred while executing the command:
0x80070005 : unknown error

(2/4) Found Microsoft Visual C++ 2005 Redistributable [Microsoft.VCRedist.2005.x86] Version 8.0.61001
This application is licensed to you by its owner.
An unexpected error occurred while executing the command:
0x80070005 : unknown error

(3/4) Found Microsoft .NET Runtime 3.1 [Microsoft.DotNet.Runtime.3_1] Version 3.1.32
This application is licensed to you by its owner.
An unexpected error occurred while executing the command:
0x80070005 : unknown error

(4/4) Found Microsoft .NET SDK 6.0 [Microsoft.DotNet.SDK.6] Version 6.0.405
This application is licensed to you by its owner.
An unexpected error occurred while executing the command:
0x80070005 : unknown error

15 package(s) have version numbers that cannot be determined. Use --include-unknown to see all results.
```

or

```
PS C:\Users\C_B-A> winget source update --verbose-logs
Updating all sources...
Updating source: msstore...
Done
Updating source: winget...
Cancelled
```

The log from the above command: 
[WinGet-2023-02-22-13-49-49.557.log](https://github.com/microsoft/winget-cli/files/10804079/WinGet-2023-02-22-13-49-49.557.log)


### Expected behavior

Winget to update its sources and upgrade apps.

### Actual behavior

Winget is not updating or upgrading.

### Environment

```shell
PS C:\Users\C_B-A> winget --info
Windows Package Manager v1.4.10173
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

Windows: Windows.Desktop v10.0.19045.2604
System Architecture: X64
Package: Microsoft.DesktopAppInstaller v1.19.10173.0

Logs: %LOCALAPPDATA%\Packages\Microsoft.DesktopAppInstaller_8wekyb3d8bbwe\LocalState\DiagOutputDir

User Settings: %LOCALAPPDATA%\Packages\Microsoft.DesktopAppInstaller_8wekyb3d8bbwe\LocalState\settings.json

Links
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Privacy Statement   https://aka.ms/winget-privacy
License Agreement   https://aka.ms/winget-license
Third Party Notices https://aka.ms/winget-3rdPartyNotice
Homepage            https://aka.ms/winget
Windows Store Terms https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/storedocs/terms-of-sale
```

comment.body:
> this helps me
> 
> ```
> # run under powershell.exe !!!
> $smpath = "$env:TEMP\source.msix"
> Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://cdn.winget.microsoft.com/cache/source.msix -OutFile $smpath
> Add-AppxPackage -Path $smpath 
> ```

same! Thank you
